pregunta: 1. What are the recommended treatment options for glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis in patients with very high fracture risk?
respuesta: For patients with glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis (GIOP) who are at very high fracture risk due to treatment with one or more courses of high-dose glucocorticoid therapy (mean dose of prednisone equivalent ≥30 mg daily for ≥30 days) or a cumulative glucocorticoid dose ≥5 g over 1 year, the 2022 American College of Rheumatology guideline conditionally recommends treating with parathyroid hormone (PTH) or parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) over anti-resorptive agents, regardless of FRAX score or bone mineral density (BMD). In addition, the guideline strongly recommends the use of oral bisphosphonates over no treatment and conditionally recommends intravenous bisphosphonates, denosumab, raloxifene, or romosozumab over no treatment.

pregunta: 2. Why is it important to reassess fracture risk in patients continuing chronic glucocorticoid therapy?
respuesta: It is important to reassess fracture risk in patients who are continuing chronic glucocorticoid (GC) therapy because reassessment allows providers to determine if patients continuing GC and osteoporosis (OP) therapy are maintaining, gaining, or losing bone mineral density (BMD), warranting possible changes in OP therapy. For patients at very high fracture risk, yearly BMD assessment until a stable BMD is reached may be preferred. This is highlighted as good clinical practice despite the low certainty of the evidence. Regular reassessment, which includes clinical fracture risk history, new symptomatic fractures, and diagnostic measures like FRAX, BMD, vertebral fracture assessment (VFA), and/or spine x-rays, ensures that changes in treatment can be made proactively to help prevent further bone deterioration and fractures.

pregunta: 8. Why is metabolic bone disease expert evaluation recommended for renal transplant recipients on chronic glucocorticoid therapy?
respuesta: Evaluation by a metabolic bone disease expert is recommended for renal transplant recipients who are on chronic glucocorticoid therapy because there is an increased risk of renal osteodystrophy when the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is less than 35 ml/min. This includes conditions such as adynamic bone disease, osteomalacia, osteitis fibrosa cystica, and mixed uremic osteodystrophy. The expert evaluation is conditionally recommended to exclude these conditions and assess for hyperparathyroidism. Once these conditions are excluded, no dose adjustment is needed when prescribing medications such as denosumab, parathyroid hormone (PTH)/PTH-related protein (PTHrP), or romosozumab, but bisphosphonates should be avoided in this group.
